name: queen
content:
queen

noun
 
 
/kwiːn/
 
/kwiːn/
Idioms
jump to other results

    female ruler

  1.  
     the female ruler of an independent state that has a royal family
    • She was crowned queen at the age of fifteen.
    • kings and queens
    • queen of… the Queen of Norway
    • Queen Victoria
    Extra Examples
    • She became queen after the sudden death of her brother.
    • England under Queen Elizabeth I
    • The banquet will be hosted by the Queen at Buckingham Palace.
    Topics Historya2, People in societya2, Politicsa2

    See full entry
  2.  
    (also queen consort)
    the wife of a king
    • Henry VII and his queen, Elizabeth of York
    • queen of… The King and Queen of Denmark attended the wedding.
    Topics People in societya2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • rightful
    • future

    See full entry
    3.

    best in group

  3. queen (of something) a woman, place or thing that is thought to be one of the best in a particular group or area
    • the queen of fashion
    • a movie queen
    • Venice, queen of the Adriatic
    see also drama queen

    4. at festival

  4. a woman or girl chosen to perform official duties at a festival or celebration
    • a carnival queen
    • a May queen (= at a festival to celebrate the coming of spring)
    • a homecoming queen
    • She was nominated for prom queen in high school.
    see also beauty queen, pearly queen

    5. in chess

  5. enlarge image
    the most powerful piece used in the game of chess that can move any number of squares in any direction    Topics Games and toysc2

    6. in cards

  6. enlarge image
    a playing card with the picture of a queen on it    Topics Games and toysc2

    7. insect

  7. a large female insect that lays eggs for the whole group
    • a queen bee
    Topics Insects, worms, etc.c2

    gay

  8. (taboo, offensive, slang) an offensive word for a gay man who behaves like a woman see also drag queen
    9. Word OriginOld English cwēn, of Germanic origin; related to quean ‘badly behaved woman or girl’.

name: Queen
content:
Queen

 
/kwiːn/
 
/kwiːn/
jump to other results
  1. a successful British pop group formed in 1971. Its singer was Freddie Mercury and its albums A Night at the Opera (1975), The Game (1980) and Innuendo (1991) as well as the song Bohemian Rhapsody (1975) were all No. 1 in Britain. The 2002 musical We Will Rock You is based on the group's music.
Check pronunciation: Queen

name: May Queen
content:
May Queen

noun
 
/ˈmeɪ kwiːn/
 
/ˈmeɪ kwiːn/
(also Queen of the May)
jump to other results
  1. a girl who is chosen in a town or village to be the central figure of traditional May Day celebrations in Britain. She wears a crown of flowers and may be driven through the streets on an open vehicle.
Check pronunciation: May Queen

name: queen bee
content:
queen bee

noun
 
/ˌkwiːn ˈbiː/
 
/ˌkwiːn ˈbiː/
jump to other results
  1. a female bee that produces eggs for the whole group of bees in a hive compare drone, worker
  2. a woman who behaves as if she is the most important person in a particular place or group
    • She was the queen bee of the society circuit.
See queen bee in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: queen bee

name: Queen Anne
content:
Queen Anne

 
/ˌkwiːn ˈæn/
 
/ˌkwiːn ˈæn/
jump to other results
  1. (1665-1714) the queen of Britain from 1702 to 1714. She was the daughter of King James II and the last of the House of Stuart. None of her 18 children lived beyond the age of 11, so when she died, her German cousin George from Hanover became King George I. Queen Anne was the last British ruler to be able to prevent Parliament from passing a law by using her power to veto (= reject) it.
  2. a style of architecture and furniture popular in England in the early 18th century, during the rule of Queen Anne. In furniture its main features were curved legs and simple attractive designs. A later style in architecture, known as Queen Anne or Queen Anne Revival, was popular in England from the 1860s, and used elements such as red brick, high narrow windows and tall chimneys. Its best-known architect was Norman Shaw (1831-1912).
Check pronunciation: Queen Anne

name: drag queen
content:
drag queen

noun
 
/ˈdræɡ kwiːn/
 
/ˈdræɡ kwiːn/
jump to other results
  1. a person, usually a man, who wears special, very bright or colourful women's clothes and make-up as part of an entertainment act
    • The show features some of London's most glamorous drag queens.
Check pronunciation: drag queen

name: drama queen
content:
drama queen

noun
 
/ˈdrɑːmə kwiːn/
 
/ˈdrɑːmə kwiːn/
(informal, disapproving)
jump to other results
  1. a person who behaves as if a small problem or event is more important or serious than it really is
    • Oh, stop being such a drama queen!

name: Queen Mary
content:
Queen Mary

 
/ˌkwiːn ˈmeəri/
 
/ˌkwiːn ˈmeri/
jump to other results
  1. Mary of Teck (1867-1953) a British queen. In 1893 she married George, Duke of York, who in 1910 became King George V. She was the mother of two kings, Edward VIII and George VI, and the grandmother of Queen Elizabeth II.
  2. the Queen Mary
     a British passenger ship built by Cunard and named after Queen Mary. It was launched by her in 1934 and won the Blue Riband in 1938, sailing between England and the US in just under four days.
Check pronunciation: Queen Mary

name: Ellery Queen
content:
Ellery Queen

 
/ˌeləri ˈkwiːn/
 
/ˌeləri ˈkwiːn/
jump to other results
  1. a detective in many US novels and short stories written between 1929 and 1971 by Frederic Dannay (1905-82) and Manfred B Lee (1905-71) under the same name of Ellery Queen. The first book was The Roman Hat Mystery (1929). There were also radio, television and film series, and Dannay and Lee also started Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine in 1941. see also detective story

name: Queen's Club
content:
Queen's Club

 
/ˈkwiːnz klʌb/
 
/ˈkwiːnz klʌb/
jump to other results
  1. a sports club in West Kensington, London, established in 1886. It is famous as a centre for real tennis and rackets, and the Queen's Club Grass Court Tennis Championships are held there every year.
Check pronunciation: Queen's Club

name: Queen Victoria
content:
Queen Victoria

 
/ˌkwiːn vɪkˈtɔːriə/
 
/ˌkwiːn vɪkˈtɔːriə/
jump to other results
  1. (1819-1901) a British queen who ruled from 1837 to 1901. She was the granddaughter of King George III and became queen after the death of King William IV. Her rule was the longest of any British king or queen, and happened at the same time as Britain's greatest period of world power and industrial development. In 1840 she married her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. They had nine children. After Albert's death Victoria took no further part in public affairs, but was persuaded to return by her prime minister Benjamin Disraeli, who gained for her the title Empress of India. She is often remembered as a bad-tempered old woman. However in her early life she was a happy and enthusiastic queen who was very popular with ordinary people.
Check pronunciation: Queen Victoria

content:
the Virgin Queen

name: the Queen Elizabeth
content:
the Queen Elizabeth

 
/ðə ˌkwiːn ɪˈlɪzəbəθ/
 
/ðə ˌkwiːn ɪˈlɪzəbəθ/
jump to other results
  1. a British passenger ship built by Cunard, the largest of its type ever built. It was named after Queen Elizabeth, later the Queen Mother, and was launched by her in 1938. It was first used in the Second World War to carry soldiers, and after the war carried passengers between England and the US. In 1972 it was destroyed by a fire. see also the QE2
Check pronunciation: the Queen Elizabeth

name: Mary, Queen of Scots
content:
Mary, Queen of Scots

 
/ˌmeəri ˌkwiːn əv ˈskɒts/
 
/ˌmeri ˌkwiːn əv ˈskɑːts/
jump to other results
  1. Mary Stuart (1542-87) the queen of Scotland from 1542 to 1567. She was the daughter of King James V of Scotland and the cousin of Queen Elizabeth I, and became queen of Scotland soon after her birth. She did not rule Scotland until 1561 and was instead brought up in France, where she was queen briefly in 1559. She was a Roman Catholic, and after her return to Scotland became involved in religious disputes with Scottish Protestants. In 1567 she was forced to give up power in favour of her son James VI (later King James I of England), and moved to England where she was held as a prisoner. In the years that followed there were several attempts by Catholic groups to make her queen of England in place of Elizabeth I, and Elizabeth finally ordered Mary's head to be cut off. Her adventures, love affairs and three marriages have been the subject of many books, plays and films. see also the Earl of Bothwell, Lord Darnley “In my end is my beginning.”motto of Mary, Queen of Scots
Check pronunciation: Mary, Queen of Scots
